verses.verse: (1 A praise and thanksgiving unto God by the faithful, who are signified by Zion,4 For the choosing, preservation, and governance of them,9 And for the plentiful blessings poured forth upon all the earth, but especially toward his Church. ) O God, praise waiteth for thee in Zion, and unto thee shall the vow be performed.
Because thou hearest the prayer, unto thee shall all (Not only the Jews but also the Gentiles in the kingdom of Christ.) flesh come.

Wicked deeds (He imputeth it to his sins and to the sins of the people, that God who was accustomed to assist them withdraweth his succor from them.) have prevailed against me: but thou wilt be merciful unto our transgressions.
Blessed is he, whom thou choosest and causest to come to thee: he shall dwell in thy courts, and we shall be satisfied with the pleasures of thine House, even of thine holy Temple.

O God of our salvation, thou wilt (Thou wilt declare thyself to be the preserver of thy Church in destroying thine enemies, as thou didst in the red Sea.) answer us with fearful signs in thy righteousness, O thou the hope of all the ends of the earth, and of them that are far off in the (As of all barbarous nations and far off.) Sea.
He establisheth the mountains by his power: and is girded about with strength.

He appeaseth the (He showeth that there is no part nor creature in the world which is not governed by God’s power and providence.) noise of the seas, and the noise of the waves thereof, and the tumults of the people.
They also that dwell in the uttermost parts of the earth, shall be afraid of thy signs; thou shalt make (Hebrew, the going forth of the morning and of the evening.) the East and the West to rejoice.

Thou (To wit, with rain.) visitest the earth, and waterest it; thou makest it very rich: the (That is, Shiloh or the rain.) river of God is full of water, thou preparest them corn; for so thou appointest (Thou hast appointed the earth to bring forth food to man’s use.) it.

Thou (By this description he showeth that all the order of nature is a testimony of God’s love toward us, who causeth all creatures to serve our necessity.) waterest abundantly the furrows thereof; thou causest the rain to descend into the valleys thereof; thou makest it soft with showers, and blessest the bud thereof.
Thou crownest the year with thy goodness, and thy steps drop fatness.
They drop upon the pastures of the wilderness: and the hills shall be compassed with gladness.

The pastures are clad with sheep; the valleys also shall be covered with corn; therefore they shout for joy, (That is, the dumb creatures shall not only rejoice for a time for God’s benefits, but shall continually sing.) and sing.
